sub_topic: Using Fourier series to solve partial differential equations
message_1:
The temperature distribution in a metal rod of length 10 cm is given by:

$$u(x, t) = 100\cos{(\frac{\pi x}{10})}\cdot e^{-kt}$$

where $x$ is the position along the rod and $t$ is time. The rod is initially at room temperature of $20$ degrees Celsius. The ends of the rod are insulated, so there is no heat flow across the boundary. Find the temperature distribution at time $t = 0.1$ seconds, if the thermal diffusivity of the metal is $k = 0.2 \text{ cm}^2/\text{s}$.
message_2:
To find the temperature distribution at time $t = 0.1$ seconds, we simply need to plug in the given values of $t$ and $k$ into the equation for $u(x, t)$:

$$u(x, 0.1) = 100\cos{(\frac{\pi x}{10})}\cdot e^{-0.2 \cdot 0.1}$$

Simplify the exponential term:

$$u(x, 0.1) = 100\cos{(\frac{\pi x}{10})}\cdot e^{-0.02}$$

Now, we have the temperature distribution at time $t = 0.1$ seconds:

$$u(x, 0.1) = 100\cos{(\frac{\pi x}{10})}\cdot e^{-0.02}$$

This equation gives the temperature at any position $x$ along the rod at time $t = 0.1$ seconds.
